hints.content: Start by understanding what it means to split the integer n into k positive integers. Each of these integers must multiply together to give you n.
Consider the constraints: you need to ensure that k is strictly less than the total number of positive divisors of n. This means that you will always have enough factors to work with.
Think about how to factor n into its prime components. This can help you understand how to distribute these factors among k integers.
To minimize the maximum difference between the integers, you should aim to keep the integers as close to each other as possible. Consider how you can achieve this with the factors of n.
When splitting n, it might be helpful to start with the largest possible factors and then break them down further if necessary. This can help you maintain balance.
Remember that the product of the integers must equal n. If you find a combination that works, check that their product is indeed n.
You can use a greedy approach to select factors. Start with the largest factors and see how you can distribute them into k parts while keeping the product equal to n.
Consider edge cases where n is a prime number or a power of a prime. These cases might limit your options for splitting n into k integers.
When you have found a potential split, calculate the maximum difference between the integers. If itâ€™s not minimized, consider adjusting the integers.
A good approach is to iterate through the divisors of n and try to form groups of k numbers. Ensure that you keep track of the maximum difference and adjust as necessary.

questionNotes: k is strictly less than the total number of positive divisors of n.
The output can be in any order.
